meanings.def: to make objects, patterns, etc. by cutting away material from a piece of wood or stone, or another hard material
examples: carve something from/out of something The statue was carved out of a single piece of stone.
The beads were carved from solid ivory.
carve something into/in something The wood had been carved into the shape of a flower.
(figurative) Over the centuries, melting snow had carved valleys in the landscape.
carve in something She carves in both stone and wood.

meanings.def: to write something on a surface by cutting into it
examples: They carved their initials on the desk.
A Latin inscription had been carved on the lid of the box.

meanings.def: to cut a large piece of cooked meat into smaller pieces for eating
examples: carve (something) | carve (somebody) something Who's going to carve the turkey?
Lunch is ready. Who's going to carve?
She taught me how to carve a leg of lamb.
We watched as the waiter expertly carved the duck.

meanings.def: to work hard in order to have a successful career, reputation, etc.
examples: carve something (out) He succeeded in carving out a career in the media.
carve something (out) for yourself She has carved a place for herself in the fashion world.
People should remember that our proposals aren't set in stone.
These rules are not set in stone.
People should remember that our proposals aren't set in stone.
These rules are not set in stone.
